newsitem.title: GERMANY: Shorter hours won't create jobs - Germany's Jagoda.
newsitem.headline: Shorter hours won't create jobs - Germany's Jagoda.

text.p: The head of Germany's jobs agency said on Thursday that a trade union proposal to cut the industrial working week to 32 hours would not create new jobs and would instead encourage companies to cut costs.
Federal Labour Office head Bernhard Jagoda said what was needed instead was greater labour market flexibility in order to win the battle to cut Germany's 4.5 million unemployed.
"If we reduce working times step-by-step, I have the great fear that this could be offset by rationalisation," Jagoda told Saarland radio.

Jagoda earlier this week announced jobless figures which showed a fall from February's 64-year record unemployment. New jobs came from hiring outdoor workers and there was no stimulus creating jobs coming from the economy.
His remarks came in response to a call by Klaus Zwickel, head of the powerful IG Metall industrial union, for a cut in the working week to try and boost job creation.
Jagoda said it was important to reach agreements which would increase the running time of industrial machinery to boost productivity, while offering workers more control over their job hours.
